CA stands aside for her to leave, the girl goes by her witho looking up, a murmur of acknowledgement. CATHARINA looks into the empty studio, craning her neck t something significant in the bare room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET is grinding pigment, her action now as smooth and e VERMEER’S, a quiet trance-like state, Interrupted by MEN' VOICES.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0/S)
dialogues.text: You might get your own and save my back. GRIET freezes. They are coming into the STUDIO. Below her of moving furniture, a grunt as the MEN lift something he

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (0/8)
dialogues.text: Maria Thins suspects it a distraction.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0/S)
dialogues.text: From painting? How could a painter ignore such an invent-

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (0/S)
dialogues.text: From finishing. They laugh. GRIET peers down into the STUDIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERMEER holds one end of the camera obscura, the MAN (VAN LEEUWENHOEK) the other. An extension, obviously home-made been put on one end and they are struggling to fit the wh contraption safely on the table.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: VAN LEEUWENHOEK talks at top speed, ideas bursting out wi time to catch his breath. November 2003  49

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Did I tell you I ground a perfect lens last week? The very smallest distortion at one edge. Careful - I was awake a great part of the night at this; the new lens is not so well-~secured as I wanted. They lift the box but as they do so VAN LEEUWENHOEK catch sight of GRIET watching from the attic. He gasps and drop end of the camera obscura with a crash.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aah! There’s a girl in your attic.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: The lens is off. GRIET hides.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Confound it, the whole thing is out of true. What's she doing up there? He starts disassembling the camera obscura as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Can you set it right?

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Hmm.. I don’t know... You see the bracket...no,no I believe it is only a little bent...if I... Hold that steady, yes, there it goes... I know who she is! Catharina complained at length - a brace of customers waiting - at the strain of running so large a household. I thought she was bragging.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Come down, Griet. (to VAN LEEUWENHOEK ) If you kept your shop in better order you wouldn't have to listen to so much talk

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: It's the talk fills my shop - and with sickness in the town that's no small matter. I am not the only draper in Delft selling fine silk in five weights but I am the only one willing and able to converse on any subject under God's sun.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (drily) Hold forth. November 2003  50

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: So Griet, now we are on the level - Antony Van Leeuwenhoek, your servant - What were you doing in the attic? Spying for Mother Thins? GRIET hesitates, this is her secret with VERMEER. But som in VAN LEEUWENHOEK'S face gives her confidence.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Grinding pigments, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Griet the Assistant, eh? What next? Have you taken a pupil at last? You won't teach me.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: You have no aptitude. She can stand in if it's working. Over there, Uncertainly GRIET takes up the pose of the model at the w The two MEN burrow under VERMEER'S cloak to see the image look more than a little absurd, a sort of lumpy pantomime

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: A little more, stop, the other way, more more... there. D'you see the diffraction- ow, my foot. GRIET’S lips curl upwards.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Stop that, Griet. GRIET tries to look solemn.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Sharply) Don’t think. You're spoiling the picture. GRIET struggles to obey. VAN LEEUWENHOEK emerges from und cloak, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: You're a tyrant. Tell her next she may not breathe, your blessed picture doesn't. (Looking at the painting) What does it mean? Who is she? GRIET holds her breath. VERMEER straightens up, turns awa

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one. A vision I had, They move away, leaving GRIET in the painting corner. November 2003

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why isn't Van Ruijven buying it? His pockets are deep enough surely, even if he never pays a bill till the next quarter but one. Did you quarrel?

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: He chooses a painter who offers wine and company.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Are you being stiff-necked, Jan? He's visited by every notable in the country - still waiting for my invitation - and your pictures are the pride of his collection.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: He has good taste. VAN LEEUWENHOEK laughs.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: It isn't modesty holds you back! Make it up with him for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: It's not that he tells me what to paint and how; I know to sup with the Devil I must take a long spoon. No, it's why he wants them. VAN LEEUWENHOEK lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: That business with the maid? You're only a painter, Jan, not his confessor.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: You know he offered to lend me more money?

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Well, if you need some maybe I could-

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: It's not the money. He’s greedy. The paintings aren't enough. He would be my Master. November 2003 51  52

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: He's used to having his way and you cross him, that's- The door opens abruptly and MARIA THINS stands there.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: It's true then. You are here.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Mistress Thins. You look well. I have the black satin- MARIA THINS ignores him, turns angrily on her son-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: You told me you were painting today. VERMEER cradles his painting hand.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: I am. I was. She is too annoyed to be able to speak to him, switches b VAN LEEUWENHOEK.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA THINS
dialogues.text: Anthony, it's time you were on your way and pray God you never have the burden of a family to interrupt your interesting notions. VAN LEEUWENHOEK bows to her.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Your servant, Mistress. Good Day Jan. Griet. MARIA THINS looks thunderstruck as she realises GRIET, st the painting pose, has witnessed this scene.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: What the Devil is she- Downstairs, girl. At once. GRIET hurries to leave. MARIA THINS turns to VERMEER agai

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Hissing) Joannis, in the Name of Christ - think! You are not the only one in this house with eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the end of the day. TANNEKE sits on a bench trying light a pipe. GRIET takes down the last of the laundry. C and MAERTGE are practising dance steps. November 2003  53

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: No need for the Fish Market tomorrow, Mistress wants eggs. She puffs at the pipe, drawing out the moment. Looks over two girls.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (lowered voice) No, she cannot abide the smell when she’s with child. GRIET, arms full of baby clothes, can’t hide her surprise

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: So soon? TANNEKE is delighted to be first with bad news.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: As if there weren't enough mouths to feed already. But what can you do? She looks up to the lit studio window significantly.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men! GRIET doesn’t want to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Did you never want children, Tanneke? Your own family.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: Dunno. Maybe I will, one day. Again GRIET is taken aback. TANNEKE laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How old did you think I was, then? Wisely GRIET doesn’t attempt to guess. If she did she mig forty.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Started with Old Mistress when I was fourteen. (Counting on her fingers) Year before Maertge was born. What‘s that, then?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (Promptly, she must have been listening all along) Twenty eight. November 2003  54

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: Twenty eight. There you are. GRIET is horrified but TANNEKE examines her beefy forearm broad girth with some satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the work does it. Few more years, you’ll thicken up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COOKING KITCHEN/GREAT HALL NIGHT
dialogues.text: GRIET must pass through the Great Hall to get to bed but not interrupt the scene before her. CATHARINA sits at the delicate keyboard of a spinet, all fretful energy released in the music, her hands floating the notes. VERMEER leans forward to turn the page for her, inhaling scent. His hand caresses her bare shoulder. A deeply sens intimate moment. GRIET sinks back in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRIET playfully runs away from PIETER. He catches her and her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET lays out colours for the day with absolute certaint precision, glancing at the painting to be sure of what is needed. She stops short, circles the easel, looking from differen angles. Very carefully and deliberately she drags the heavy lion- chair out of the foreground of the setting. She looks at what she’s done, astonished by her own boldn The key turns in the lock, she hurries to the door, breat Instead of CATHARINA, CORNELIA is at the door, holding th bunch of keys with pride. She eyes GRIET intently, taking advantage of her surprise.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: (Accusing) What were you doing? November 2003  55 GRIET is wrong-footed, tries to keep calm.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Where's your mother? CORNELIA is peering into the studio over GRIET'S shoulder

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: She has a headache. You're to mind the little ones this morning.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET sits on the bench in the sunshine with baby FRANCIS her knee. LISBETH and ALEYDIS are playing with their doll CORNELIA interfering in their game. MAERTGE is sewing. VERMEER comes down the street, CORNELIA and LISBETH run t him. He goes into the house without looking at GRIET. She tense.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: GRIET carries her candle through the darkened house and upstairs. She stands outside the studio door, hardly dari go in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO NIGHT
dialogues.text: The room is neat and empty. No sign of work, the window c the cupboard locked. GRIET holds up her candle to see the painting. He has made her change, painted out the chair. stares, exultant, at what she has done.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET and VERMEER are at work preparing colours; GRIET gr bone black, VERMEER kneading a paste of precious blue lap lazuli. VERMEER clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Why did you move the chair? GRIET pauses, not uncertain, but wanting to say rightly w means.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: When you took the map from the painting of Mistress Van Ruijven - it was better. November 2003  56 She puts down the muller, thinking it through carefully.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The clear space below her arm, it balances the wall above now. She is not trapped. She has finished and looks up at him for his reaction but stands still and silent for a long time. At last he start working again, GRIET picks up her muller too. Almost at o stops.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: So. I never thought to learn from a maid. They are both very still, their hands next to each other bright pigments. His beautiful long, white fingers, so cl hers they can feel each other’s warmth. Then suddenly a clatter of footsteps and voices below; MA THIN’S voice, a warning tone.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: Griet, are you up there?

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: VERMEER climbs down the ladder. MARIA THINS is at the doo eyes flick anxiously up to the ATTIc. CATHARINA fumes behind her, infuriated at her exclusion, hair half-dressed.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: One of my tortoiseshell combs is gone. It is an accusation not a statement. VERMEER stands at the window, looking out. GRIET reads di in MARIA THINS’ scowl. CATHARINA's eyes rest on a smear o scarlet madder on GRIET's arm. She draws herself up with dignity. She is totally vindicated.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps now I will be listened to in my own home. She's nothing but trouble. She sweeps her skirt round to go downstairs, MARIA THINS behind, her clever, soothing words for once pass unheeded CORNELIA’S face at the door, a brief triumphant smirk bef follows them. Suddenly GRIET understands. GRIET and VERMEER are left alone in the studio. A painful silence, punctuated by the WOMEN’S VOICES from below. VERMEER turns abruptly and crosses the room, not meeting eyes. As he reaches the door: November 2003  57

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Master. I did not do it. He hesitates, back turned.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (A whisper) Help me. On his face, frozen in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: The whole house in uproar: CATHARINA furious, CORNELIA cr TANNEKE red-faced with indignation. VERMEER goes from room to room, pulling back bed covers, sweeping stuff off shelves, the WOMEN squawking behind hi hens. He finds GRIET’S tortoiseshell comb under CORNELIA‘S matt

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Cornelia!

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARIA THINS ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: It is MARIA THINS who takes up her cane while CATHARINA t away weeping. CORNELIA’S face is white and defiant, her g eyes like stone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL DAY
dialogues.text: VERMEER and MARTA THINS sit at the oak table while CATHAR paces to and fro, kicking her skirts out of her way. Ther something a little unhinged, disturbing, about her anger, way it controls her body, jerks her this way and that. GRIET and TANNEKE stand and face the family, but CATHARIN as if GRIET weren't in the room.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: She’s dishonest. Always sneaking around, skiving her work. GRIET looks towards VERMEER, hoping he will explain, defe He is studying his boots. MARIA THINS glares at her warni

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tanneke has complained of it. Creeping upstairs all day long. She bumps against the table in her anger, thumps it with open hand. VERMEER half-reaches out to her. She stops abr she might be going to hit him. MARIA THINS decides to tak charge. November 2003  58

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: My daughter is right. There has been too much sneaking about. Her tone includes her son-in-law in the charge.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: (A fresh outburst) I only took her out of charity. If I'd thought- MARIA THINS cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: With another child due we need the extra help. CATHARINA is quelled for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Griet, fit in all your duties and do not slack or it will be the worse for you. Her eyes are dark and beady, calculating, holding them al her grasp.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I shall invite Master Van Ruijven. Joannis must have a new commission. And it will have to be a big one, several figures. VERMEER cradles his painting hand in the other protective he neither speaks nor looks at any of them. MARIA THINS c her hands, dismissing them all.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now back to work.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MARIA THINS ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: CATHARINA is very nervous, she brushes the GIRLS’ hair, i their protests. GRIET helps MAERTGE into her first grown-up dress, of whi is shyly proud. MAERTGE will never be a beauty but dresse her hair curled and ribboned, she begins to look like a l only a couple of years younger than GRIET but already her set on an utterly different course. CATHARINA sees them together - the mousy, richly-dressed the linen-capped maid who effortlessly eclipses her — and mouth tightens.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Maertge! Come here. November 2003  59 Obediently MAERTGE goes to her MOTHER. CATHARINA’S hands still busy taming CORNELIA’S hair, she can think of nothi keep MAERTGE with her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t gawk your head like that, child. It’s ugly. MAERTGE droops instantly. CORNELIA pokes her tongue out a sister, winces as CATHARINA tugs at her hair. NOISE from outside, the guests arriving. They all run to out of the window. EXT. VERMEER HOUSE DAY - THEIR P.O.V. VAN RUIJVEN, with his wife and daughter, arrives at the h grand style on their barge. Their clothes are even richer voice booms louder than before. VERMEER, stepping forward greet him, looks shabby in comparison.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL DAY
dialogues.text: As the honoured guests VAN RUIJVEN sits at one end of the his WIFE EMILIE on VERMEER’S right. VAN RUIJVEN meets CATHARINA‘S eye with a lascivious grin.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: I swear you get lovelier every time I see you, Catharina. Do you paint yourself? He laughs again, then licks a finger and rubs it on CATHA cheek, examines it for signs of make-up. As an afterthoug licks it again, as if he had dipped it in honey. CATHARIN smiles at him, a woman of the world.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: One painter in the house is enough. Raising my children is all my pride.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Ah, little Maertge. Filling out nicely, isn’t she? MAERTGE, sitting between her MOTHER and FATHER, quails at attention, ears burning red.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All those girls, eh. Lads swarming round ‘em like flies before long. If I were a few years younger... GRIET serves EMILIE VAN RUIJVEN, as calm and silent as he painting. MARIA THINS turns to VAN RUIJVEN with a smile. Noverber 2003  60

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: A connoisseur in everything, Master Van Ruijven. But you should be faithful to one mistress above all others. VAN RUIJVEN is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Art. Your name will surely be famed as one of the great patrons, the Maecenas of Delft. With your exquisite taste, your subtle understanding of allegory and allusion- VAN RUIJVEN laughs, head back.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Damn, you could sell sour milk to cows, woman. What do you want now? MARIA THINS straightens the delicate white lace on her cu

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: A group painting. A family portrait perhaps... She glances at VERMEER, knowing he won't like this. He concentrates on helping MAERTGE.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yourself and Emilie. Your lovely daughter too. No sign of interest from VAN RUIJVEN. MARIA THINS pushes further.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or a Merry Company. Wine and a good meal on the table; a still life with your friends all about. (A beat) Music and dancing.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Better, better. GRIET serves MARIA THINS. CATHARINA puts a hand on VAN RU arm.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: It will have to be a Slow Measure if he paints it. VAN RUIJVEN leans closer to her, shamelessly ogling her cleavage.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: That‘s the only dance I know. November 2003  61 They giggle together like smutty children. GRIET goes rou serve VAN RUIJVEN, head down, shoulders hunched, trying t invisible.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s truth in what you say, Maria, larded in with all those sweet words. It so happens your son-in-law is a damn fine painter, as good as any Amsterdam fellow I’d say- He breaks off to take a mouthful of meat.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bh, that’s good. Fat Tanneke learnt to cook at last. What I mean is, I‘1ll swallow your bait, the big picture, several figures, a Merry Company. But not a family portrait...

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I’m to put up with all those tedious hours of sitting I need something to rest my eyes on. I want her in the painting. He reaches back with one arm and grabs GRIET, pulling her forward. VERMEER is on his feet. CATHARINA shrieks, VAN R releases his grip, still smiling. His sharp eyes are on V as he sinks back into his chair, the reaction noted. MARIA THINS licks her lips, eyes darting from one end of table to the other. VERMEER runs one fingertip round his wineglass till it sings.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A tavern scene, why not? That would make a change for you. Griet could serve me. GRIET glances at CATHARINA, who is leaning forward, cheek flushed, eyes burning, ready to explode in fury. VAN RUIJ stuffs another lump of meat in his mouth, enjoying himsel

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, what do you say? Can I have her?

dialogues.speaker: INT. MEAT MARKET DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET waits to be served. A fly crawls slowly over the me huddle of WOMEN nudge and stare. GRIET looks away, mortif There is no sign of PIETER. PAUL leans over to her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There's been talk of you. GRIET flushes, her face tight.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I‘ve done nothing to be talked of. November 2003  62 PAUL shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Van Ruijven’s cook. Says you’re to be painted with her master. You'll have heard about him and the maid that was painted before. Agitated, GRIET stuffs the meat in the shopping pail.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: You shouldn't believe gossip. PAUL laughs.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't. Not the half of it. (A beat) I‘1l tell Pieter you asked after him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DELFT STREETS DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET hurries back through the crowds, the girls trotting keep up.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: Griet! Wait! PIETER hurries along the street after them. He has a carc one shoulder, his apron is smeared with blood. Passers-by round in surprise. PIETER arrives, breathless. Props the carcass on stiff hi legs.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear what-

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I heard. He waits for her denial.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: No smoke without fire, they say.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Is that what you think?

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: No. I.. You're only a maid. What can you do? GRIET bites her lip.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I must get back. Tanneke.. November 2003  63 She starts walking again, the GIRLS beside her. PIETER sh the carcass and comes after them.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: Griet! Don't walk away. Listen to me. MAERTGE holds GRIET’S hand possessively, CORNELIA glares He comes closer, lowers his voice to a murmur.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember who you are, Griet. Don’t get caught up in his world. She turns on him angrily.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: You listen to me, Pieter the Butcher. I am only a maid but I will never give in to Master van Ruijven.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: I don't speak of van Ruijven. EXT. VERMEER HOUSE — DAY GRIET hurries back to the house. Too late she sees VERMEE VAN RUIJVEN talking by the canal and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Hey, you. Girl. Griet. Come here! GRIET turns slowly. VAN RUIJVEN comes up to meet her, VER following reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where were you today, Griet? I missed you. VAN RUIJVEN smiles sideways at VERMEER, winks at GRIET.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We both did. I tried to keep him amused but all I got for my pains was my face to the wall. He leans close, confiding.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hear you've been of great use to your Master, pretty Griet. All that grinding and stirring, eh. VAN RUIJVEN is delighted at the effect of his jibes on GR VERMEER. November 2003  64

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Master and Maid - there's a tune we all know. And you can practise it together, now we’ve made our bargain, eh Jan. You won’t forget, will you? VERMEER shakes his head stiffly, like a puppet. EMILIE VA RUIJVEN and a teenage DAUGHTER come up behind them.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. You’1ll want to make a start on that before we come again. VAN RUIJVEN tucks his wife’s arm into his. GRIET looks up MASTER. His grey eyes slide past hers and away. He is ang hurries into the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET sweeps the studio; orange peel and crumbs mark VAN RUIJVEN'S place among the chairs and instruments. The key in the lock but it is not CATHARINA. VERMEER stands in th doorway as if he too were unable, or unwilling, to come i STUDIO.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Griet. He gestures to the painting corner. Two tapestry-covered chairs have been arranged around the harpsichord, a lute on one, a bass viol propped against t wall. VERMEER busies himself at the table. GRIET looks at paintings on the wall, both taken from downstairs. One is a landscape, trees and an open road into the dista The other is of a man and two women. The man is buying th one’s favours from the old, he already has an arm round h [The Procuress, Dirk van Baburen] VERMEER clears his throat and GRIET looks round, full of foreboding, waiting for her instructions. But none come. simply sits and stares at her. And stares. His face wears familiar abstracted expression. Her eyes slowly fill with He is going to paint her. She looks bleakly at the musical instruments lying around

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: What should I...(pretend to play)? VERMEER frowns.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: No! I have already begun the group painting. You are not to sit with Master Van Ruijven. That much is agreed. November 2003  65 The tears that threatened before now spill down her cheek

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. VERMEER stands up abruptly, profoundly ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: I am to paint you alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: My daughter must not hear of this ‘other’ painting. MARIA THINS counts out coins while GRIET waits with the s pail.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In her condition... GRIET looks down at the coins in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Ma'am. What of Master van Ruijven.. MARIA THINS fingers the handle of her cane.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: It is to hang in his private cabinet, with a curtain over. Gimlet eyes on GRIET to see how she takes this. She turns to go back up her private staircase.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s no fool, mind you. And he won’t be taken for one, so don't think otherwise. You're a fly in his web.(To herself) We all are. Joannis should have gone about it another way.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CANAL EVENING
dialogues.text: GRIET'S sombre face reflected for a moment before the pit breaks the surface.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOUSE EVENING
dialogues.text: Carrying the pitcher in she meets VERMEER returning home, cloak wrapped round him. He holds the door open. As she p he murmurs in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning. November 2003  66 She hesitates for a moment, heart racing. She can feel hi on her, the warmth of his body.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I cannot. I have work...

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Find a way. He moves on into the house.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Look out of the window. Down at the table. Away. He frowns. It isn't working. Surrounding GRIET are all the “props" familiar from the paintings - The silver bowl and jug, the studded box, pow brush, an open book. CATHARINA’S yellow bodice hangs on a GRIET is hedged in by things. VERMEER pulls things away, different table carpet into place, pushes a chair across, frantically building walls between himself and her. GRIET watches.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: (Bravely) These are ladies’ things.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: You want me to paint you with a mop in your hands? He is closing shutters: slam, slam. The studio grows dark darker.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: (Gentler) No. I don't know... (A beat) Perhaps the costume. What if... He reaches for the yellow mantle. GRIET plucks up courage

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I cannot wear her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: (A beat) No. He looks at her across the table. November 2003  67

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am not to paint you as a maid. Or a lady. What then? GRIET doesn’t answer. VERMEER keeps looking. Suddenly he pulling everything away, chair, table, bowls and boxes, a swept away. Until there is nothing between them, she stan alone, in the last patch of light.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. I will paint you as I first saw you. Not a maid. You. CLOSE ON: VERMEER‘S broad brush painting the first shadow bottom corner, bone black and burnt umber. Powerful strok obliterating the pale ground.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL EVENING
dialogues.text: GRIET reaches up on tiptoe to get a dish, white arm and n full stretch. CATHARINA sees her husband staring, spellbo

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Jan. My necklace. She holds up the ribbons of her necklace for him to tie. at him in the mirror as he does so; a seductive smile, an casual adjustment of her bodice to reveal more of her magnificent bosom. Quite unaware he ties the ribbons and out.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: I‘1l be in the studio till dinner. MARIA THINS watches from the fireplace, puffing silently pipe. CATHARINA sees GRIET in the background of her refle

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: (Acid) Haven’t you finished yet

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: VERMEER mixes lead-white with crimson lake: pale and butt soft under his palette knife. His hand drizzling in more oil, the paint grows richer and creamier. The brush poised to paint. VERMEER looks over to GRIET by window, looking out. Clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Look at me. Turn your head, not your shoulders. She adjusts her position, seated, looking over her left shoulder, the light falling on her right cheek. Face encl her cap, her mouth shut. She stares at the floor. November 2003  68

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at me. Slowly she raises her eyes to meet his but can't hold his The brush still poised.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at me. Her eyes waver and meet his again. His brush blanks out t downcast eyes in the painting. He lets out a sigh, almost shudder of pleasure. VERMEER'S face, intent, alight. His whole being involved act of painting: nothing else in the world. The brush on the palette, stroking the canvas. Now that h it, there is nothing tentative about his painting. The shadow of GRIET'S eyebrow, the intersection of curves and down. VERMEER'S eyes drinking in every detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERMEER is working on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: The point of your cap. Fold it back. GRIET pushes the long point back onto her shoulder, revea her jaw and cheek. She swallows, feeling exposed. Her lip pressed tight. Her eyes waver and meet his again.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never sat so close before.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: How long have I been here, sir? He changes brushes, continues to paint.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. GRIET strains to hold her twisted pose. VERMEER is starin her again.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take off your cap. GRIET reaches up then stops, her hand protective on the w linen.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: No, sir. I cannot. November 2003  69

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Cannot? GRIET drops her head. In the painting behind her: The young woman, bare-headed, back in surrender, while the client and Madam, heads cove press forward on her.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Will not.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: I need to see your face, the cap covers too much. There’s some cloth in the storeroom. GRIET goes into the little storeroom. There is no catch o door, no need for one.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STOREROOM DAY
dialogues.text: There is a trunk of clothes in the corner; props for use paintings; cloths to cover the table; gentlemen’s sashes; trimmings from CATHARINA’S rich velvet gown. GRIET finds strips of cloth and lays them in front of her. She reaches up and unties her cap, releases an unruly man blonde hair. She lifts one of the cloths to wrap round her hair, looks the mirror. Sees a movement and turns to find him standin the doorway. Looking at her. Not at GRIET the Maid, but at her. The re secret GRIET. Desire holding him transfixed in the doorwa She returns his gaze, her hair tumbled round her face, li parted, bold, liberated, naked. The CHILDREN'S VOICES from downstairs. VERMEER backs away

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET folds clothes into the tall wardrobe. The stiff blu bodice worn by the girl in the Pitcher painting. The yell satin mantle, trimmed with fur. CATHARINA sits by the fire with VAN RUIJVEN. MAERTGE and CORNELIA are working on an embroidery frame, though CORNE far more interested in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Emilie enjoys sitting, God knows why. If only he’d let one do something else. November 2003  70 CATHARINA offers him the sewing on her lap. He pretends a dainty stitches, hands it back laughing.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you agree, or you'd be up there getting painted all the time. Why not, with such a good- looking wife? CATHARINA falters, upset.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: I have the household to run, you know. I can’t be forever up and down.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: There you are ~ "Life goes on". I mean God knows I admire the paintings, extravagantly - Christ, I pay enough for them - but I am flesh and blood, I must feed my grosser parts. CATHARINA glances at the girls, wondering if she should s them out. They are bent studiously over their frame. GRIE dead still behind the wardrobe door.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not to deny I may be consoled in a painting for what I cannot have in the flesh. Hunger is the best sauce, eh. GRIET presses her face against the cool, starched linen.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I had you against my private wall, for instance, painted by your artful husband, I could take pleasure at will in your charms and he none the wiser. CATHARINA laughs as best she can.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: I never think painting so lively as when you speak of it. VAN RUIJVEN takes a long draught of wine.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: You know I’ve a mind to go up and surprise him sometime - in the act.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: But you said yourself it’s very dull.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Oh, not with Emilie. When he’s alone with some young beauty. November 2003  71

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must have noticed how he never bothers with old women. Only young and pretty ones. On their own. He helps himself to another glass of wine. CATHARINA does best to ignore his meaning.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: You'll have to wait then. He makes only one painting at a time, though my mother has often pressed him otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: (Smug) Indeed? GRIET listens in terror.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: He claims he cannot hold two in his head, though when I consider all I must manage with the house and children... VAN RUIJVEN secretly gives CORNELIA a sip of wine. She sc her face up in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I like it. VAN RUIJVEN gives her a squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: That’s my girl. They giggle and whisper together, both looking over at GR CATHARINA looks up and catches CORNELIA taking another si is shocked, though she tries to laugh it off.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Master Van Ruijven, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: VAN LEEUWENHOEK gazes quizzically at GRIET‘S strange turb head gear.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: What is she meant to be?

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: It is Griet’s invention. Ask her. VAN LEEUWENHOEK is struck by the casual intimacy of this. is trembling with the strain of holding her twisted pose. VERMEER scowls at the painting.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Whatever it is, it becomes you, Griet. November 2603  72 VAN LEEUWENHOEK wants to break the tension that thickens the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jan, did I tell you of the meeting tomorrow? Optics and lenses. You should speak on painting.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: I have nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: The camera obscura then. You know more about light than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: I know? Every painting I start again at the beginning, I’ll never know. VERMEER stabs a brush angrily towards a canvas propped on table - the Concert painting.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s what happens when one pays heed to theory. A one-point perspective of nothing. A myriad of chalk lines going this way and that. Small bl colour dotted disjointedly over the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: It's promising. Do you have the small lens? I want to show it at the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: I'll fetch it. VERMEER goes out. VAN LEEUWENHOEK turns back to GRIET.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: Rest a minute, why don’t you? Gratefully GRIET moves. VAN LEEUWENHOEK looks at her pain He is startled by what he sees. [We, like GRIET, do not s painting] His eyes flick from her to the painting and bac

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is this? Not his usual manner. Not at all. (A beat) It's for Master Van Ruijven, is that so? Mistress Thins will be pleased. He hesitates, needing to warn her, wanting to be fair.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hmm. You do see his interest in you is partly because Master Van Ruijven.. How should I put this? November 2003  73 GRIET frowns. He examines the painting again.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He sees things as he wants them to be, perfected by him. Everything serves the painting, everything. He doesn't think of the consequences. You must. He looks at GRIET, his eyes kindly, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There's no bridge across this water. You understand me, Griet? GRIET dips her head, but the head dress doesn't hide her She looks up again.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I do not think he would hurt me, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: VAN LEEUWENHOEK
dialogues.text: (Gently) How much do you know of men?

dialogues.speaker: INT. COOKING KITCHEN DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET chops vegetables. A moment of reflection before she the pattern into the pot.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET, utterly still in her pose, almost as if she were t painting. There is now a black drape behind her. VERMEER sits at the easel, dissatisfied. Tries one brush another, stands and stares at her, goes back to the paint

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Open your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Open your mouth. GRIET is horrified. But what can she do? She licks her li opens them.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lick your lips. Again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL NIGHT
dialogues.text: GRIET brings in a wine jug and glasses. Only MARIA THINS up, sharp-eyed. November 2003  74 VERMEER is going through CATHARINA’S jewel box, searching something. CATHARINA moves slowly, easing herself off the already heavy with the new baby.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Jan, please. He brings over the box, settles on a low stool and massag feet between his hands. CATHARINA is dressed in her fine velvet. She stifles a ya

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am so tired. GRIET pours their wine, sets it in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Wear these. He holds out her big pearl earrings, glossy white drops n in his hand. CATHARINA smiles, delighted by this attentio

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I must be there. The City Fathers have asked... There might be a commission.. (Seeing the earrings) Ah.. good. Look, Griet. CATHARINA swings round.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That point of light in the shadow of the neck, leading the eye.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Jant GRIET'S eyes meet VERMEER‘S. She sees that he has found w needs. That he is pitiless. MARIA THINS sees it too.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: VERMEER is arranging the setting of The Concert. The Conc painting, half-covered, has progressed considerably. GRIE hurries in.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Sir. Do not ask this of me. He knows exactly what she’s talking about.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: It is needed.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: My ears are not pierced. November 2003  75 He laughs at such a mundane excuse. But GRIET isn’t laugh she is angry.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've done everything you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: The composition - it’s not balanced.

dialogues.speaker: GRIE
dialogues.text: {Stubbornly) Sometimes you paint without a model.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: You want me to imagine how the earring would look? She wont give in.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: She will find out. Nor will he.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: This has to be, Griet. See for yourself. He insists that she look as he uncovers her painting. GRI covers her mouth in horror. WE SEE only her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: (A whisper) Oh. You looked inside me.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DELFT STREETS DUSK
dialogues.text: GRIET hurries along, her shawl pulled tight round her sho head down. INT. APOTHECARY‘'S DUSK The APOTHECARY smiles when he sees it is her.

dialogues.speaker: APOTHECARY
dialogues.text: Well then. What will it be today? I set aside some lapis-

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: It‘s- it’s for me. The APOTHECARY'S expression changes. He is sharp-eyed, he see trouble in her face. His quick fingers continue to sh dried leaves into a leather apron. November 2003  76

dialogues.speaker: APOTHECARY
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s that way, is it? (Reluctant) I have a draught if you want to bring it off. There is more disappointment in his eyes than disapproval takes his meaning.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Oh no. No. I need something to numb the skin. I have money. She pulls coins from her pocket. The OLD MAN scans her fa again, goes off grumbling, knowing something's wrong. GRIET goes to pull her cap forward, her finger tip touche ear and stops there.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC NIGHT
dialogues.text: GRIET looks at the tiny vial of oil, tips some onto a handkerchief and rubs it onto her earlobe. She heats a needle in the candle flame. Clutching the needle in trembling fingers she stares into mirror from downstairs. Her frightened face reflected in candlelight. FOOTSTEPS on the stairs. Into the STUDIO below. GRIET hid needle and vial. MARIA THINS comes up through the trap do breathing hard. She gives GRIET a long searching look.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: Well, girl? What’s to be done? GRIET says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You may fool the men with your downcast eyes. Master Van Ruijven wants his paintings and he will bear no more delay. MARIA THINS' bony hand on the black cane trembles, for th time she seems vulnerable, frightened even.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've protected you, for his sake and yours but if he crosses Van Ruijven over this he will lose him. Then what? It makes her angry to be so helpless, begging a maid for She glares at GRIET.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Flood water seeps under the door and the house comes down. I won't let that happen here. November 2003  17

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTYARD DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET hangs up sheets in the courtyard. Strong arms grab from behind, pinning her arms by her side. A voice whispe thick and hot in her ear:

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Got you! GRIET struggles silently, terrified, but VAN RUIJVEN is f stronger.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold still. I want to look at you. GRIET writhes to get free, scared and angry. He turns her round to face him, swathed in sheets.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me, girl, how do you get on up there? Has he found his composition? Do you inspire him? Do you move him? Does the Master's brush unlock the secrets of your heart? His tone is leering but his sharp eyes miss nothing. He c Griet's face exactly.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! Ripe as a plum and still unplucked. VAN RUIJVEN is disconcerted, angry, he did not expect thi

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is he playing at? She looks away, face hidden by her cap. He pulls is back roughly. A grunt of satisfaction as his hand tangles in h hair.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He made a bargain you know, he paints you at my pleasure. He is right up against her again. She pushes him away, he her wrists. GRIET writhes to get free, scared and angry. holds both her wrists with one hand, yanks the chemise of shoulder with the other.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have waited long enough. What a great fool he is. He paws at her skirts, her legs give way and she starts t He twists one arm behind her back, forcing her up again. November 2003  78 GRIET'S eyes search desperately for something to stop him the shadow of the passage she sees someone watching. CORNELIA. GRIET pleads with her eyes. CORNELIA returns he her face cat-like, impenetrable. She turns away slowly, deliberately, disappears. GRIET wants to cry. VAN RUIJVEN is unbuckling himself, GRIET struggles harder Manages to free one arm, claw at his face. He snarls. The wrestle till he has both arms pinned again.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't fight me, girl. Breathing hard he crushes her against the copper, grotesq reflections swim in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (O/S)
dialogues.text: (Petulant) Griet. Griet! She is coming along the corridor towards the back of the VAN RUIJVEN lets GRIET go, quickly straightens his clothi

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIJVEN
dialogues.text: Not a word. You'll lose your place. He‘d never look at you again. He steps out to meet CATHARINA, all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VAN RUIUVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear. There you are. Your maid kept me with some cock and bull story.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC DAWN
dialogues.text: Cold dawn light. GRIET slides her finger through fine-gro rose madder, a red streak across the stone table. Her tor chemise waits to be mended.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTYARD DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET pours water into the copper, every movement an effo arms like lead. Someone grabs her from behind.

dialogues.speaker: MAERTGE
dialogues.text: Surprise! GRIET spins round, ready to fight - to find MAERTGE and t other CHILDREN all smiling at her. MAERTGE has a package she hands over shyly.

dialogues.speaker: MAERTGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For your name day. I made it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: I thought of the surprise. November 2003  79 A perfectly innocent smile. With trembling hands GRIET un her present: a child-made lace collar.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Thank you. The CHILDREN clamour for her to put it on. She holds it u her neck - there are bruises from where VAN RUIJVEN held and they admire her.

dialogues.speaker: MAERTGE
dialogues.text: You’re beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIA
dialogues.text: Take off your cap. Then you’ll look like a lady. That tell-tale smirk. GRIET pulls off the collar.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I've work to do.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET is on her hands and knees clearing the grate. MARIA comes in hurriedly.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: My daughter is out for the day. She unlocks CATHARINA’S jewel box.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do it now. She thrusts the open box towards GRIET, who is still wipi smuts from her hands. Reluctantly she takes the pearl ear out of their velvet nest. The seconds seem to crawl.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: VERMEER watches GRIET, her partner in this slow dance. Sh off her cap, puts on the turban. Rubs the oil of cloves o ear lobe. Heats the needle in a candle flame. She holds out the earrings.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: You do it. Her eyes widen at her own boldness. He opens his mouth to then says nothing. He steps up to the chair and takes the pearls. Mixing oil into lead-white, oozing creamily under the sha knife. November 2003  80 He touches her earlobe, she gasps. He rubs the soft flesh between his forefinger and thumb then pulls it taut and w other hand pierces her skin with the needle. A scarlet gl blood glistens on the white skin. He takes a breath, forc twisted silver wire of the earring through the hole. The pain is excruciating, her eyes brim with tears. Laying on a grey ghost of paint among shadows, the under- of the pearl. His fingers brush her jaw, gently trace the bruises on he She closes her eyes, inhaling his smell. A thick white clot of paint twisted off the brush in a mo for the highlight. He blots the tears that spill down her cheek and rubs his thumb slowly along her lips, her open mouth. Pale sable hairs across the crimson of her lips, a trail white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRIET pushes her way through busy streets.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TAVERN NIGHT
dialogues.text: The benches are crowded, a jostling, careless press. Admi catcalls and whistles follow GRIET as she makes her way t the DRINKERS. PIETER’S back is turned, he doesn’t see her approach. His nudges him and moves away. PIETER stares in frank astonis

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: Griet! She takes him by the hand and leads him out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY DAY
dialogues.text: A narrow alley behind the BEAST MARKET, the bellowing of mixes into the background clatter. GRIET tugs PIETER afte presses him against the wall. Pulls his face down to hers kisses him passionately. He responds, bewildered but thri She moves his hand to her backside, turning till she is a the wall. She closes her eyes. PIETER doesn’t question hi fortune.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: PIETER watches as GRIET carefully adjusts her clothes, sm her hair under her white cap. He pulls out a long wavy st and kisses it, joyfully intimate. November 2003  81

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: Sweet Griet. She reties her cap. Her ear is bleeding a little.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Griet, don't rush away. Where are you going? He grabs her by the shoulders so she must face him.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave that house, join me and Paul at the Market. She meets his eyes levelly, very still.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I have to go back

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: I'll fetch your things. We'll send someone.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PIETER
dialogues.text: Griet. Our own life. Answering to no one. Don‘t go. Marry me. She puts a hand on his cheek, kisses him. Walks away. He leans against the wall, head down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET drops the earrings in MARIA THINS’ wrinkled hand. A and her madam. CORNELIA watches from the bed, her cat-like eyes unblinki

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: the raised lid of the harpsichord. GRIET cleans studio, alone and silent. The Concert painting is on the almost finished. The other - her painting - is propped ag the wall, covered. She avoids them both. VOICES are raised downstairs; an almighty row is brewing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRS OUTSIDE STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: Feet tumbling up the stairs: CORNELIA’S little shoes lead MARIA THINS’ stick, CATHARINA slow and heavy. November 2003  82

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET braces herself. The door crashes open, a tidal wave anger and distress,

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: No, I will not be calm. Am I a child? Dees no one speak the truth to me in my own house? CORNELIA is snivelling, frightened by her MOTHER’S passio

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: By all the Saints, if you would stop screaming for a moment I can expl-

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: More lies. I don’t want to hear any more of your lies, Mother. I have a right to know. But, finding herself at last in the forbidden room, CATHA falls silent, afraid. VERMEER is the last to enter, quietly, the eye of the sto meets GRIET’S eyes across the room. CATHARINA recovers herself a little.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So. No more hiding now. Here I am. I want to see this painting. VERMEER makes a weary gesture.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: There‘s no point. CATHARINA flares up again.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: No point! I am too stupid to look at a painting now. A savage finger at GRIET.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She can’t read! You know that? MARIA THINS pulls forward a chair.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: Sit down, you’ll exhaust yourself. CATHARINA ignores her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Why can’t I look? What have you done? November 2003  83 VERMEER is by the easel, his accustomed place.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: It's a commission. Gone in a few days. You need never see. CATHARINA is laughing and crying. Sinks onto the chair in middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: They're just paintings. Pictures for money. They mean nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: (Desperate) Is it true she wore my pearls? VERMEER cannot answer. CATHARINA groans in anguish.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How could you? How could you? She heaves herself up and stands in front of The Concert painting, breathing heavily, staring. Then she bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s backwards. Backwards. Look at him - fat arse spilling off the chair. My God, I'm not the only one that’s been had. MARIA THINS laughs too, her dry, cracked laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA THINS
dialogues.text: That's right. He wanted a portrait and he got one.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: And there’s yours, Mother. She points at the old hag in the Procuress painting.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I always hated that picture and now I know why. My mother the whore-monger.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Catharina! Enough. CATHARINA blinks, turns round slowly to him. A wide, dang smile.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Why? Was painting enough for him? Was it enough for you? (A beat) Show me the other. November 2003  84

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: You'll make yourself ill. VERMEER moves towards her slowly, cautiously. She stares with shining eyes, then quick as a snake, grabs a palette from the work table.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: Show me. VERMEER faces her, arms wide, palms out.

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Very well. Never taking his eyes from her he lifts down the Concert painting and puts the other on the easel. Tenderly lifts cover. Everyone cranes to look. GRIET, behind the easel, only their reactions. VERMEER looks oddly peaceful, a work achieved. MARIA THIN glances at GRIET, her lips a thin, bitter line, her eyes silence. CATHARINA’S face sags, mouth agape.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: {A whisper) It's obscene. Everyone will see your... Sin... She gasps for breath. The words are torn from her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Anguished) Why don’t you paint me?

dialogues.speaker: VERMEER
dialogues.text: Because you don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA
dialogues.text: And she does! Her words hang in the air: the truth. Suddenly she lunges at the painting with the knife. But V is too quick for her, grabs her wrist so hard it hurts, s cries out. He is blazing, his fury all the more terrifying for its quietness. She goes limp in his grasp and he lets her go. CATHARINA backs away, finds CORNELIA to cling to. A singl glance of hatred at GRIET.

dialogues.speaker: CATHARINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get her out of here. Get out of my house. GRIET has been waiting for this but even so it falls like whiplash. November 2003  85 Her eyes seek out VERMEER, although she can hear CATHARIN drawn hiss of fury. He is infinitely sad, infinitely dist

dialogues.speaker: INT. GREAT HALL DAY
dialogues.text: Wearing her Sunday best clothes, GRIET takes her aprons a from the linen cupboard. CATHARINA’S yellow mantle hangs silky smooth and glowing. GRIET‘S hand runs along the rim of the silver bowl, a las glimpse of its multi-fractured reflections.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VERMEER HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: Carrying her small bundle, GRIET walks through the series rooms. TANNEKE stands framed in the Cooking Kitchen doorw arms folded. Left to manage alone again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET goes up the stairs and along the corridor to the ST The door is shut fast. She stands outside listening. Sile

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO DAY
dialogues.text: VERMEER sits on his painting stool, every nerve strained listen, wanting her to come in but unable to call her. Hi painting hand is balled tight as a fist. He hears GRIET'S footsteps leaving. VERMEER is left alone in the studio, a blank canvas waiti the easel behind him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VERMEER HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: GRIET walks away from the house, her bundle under her arm wont look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VAN RUIJVEN sits alone in his cabinet with the painting o GRIET. It gives him no pleasure, after all. He draws a cu over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRIET walks across the great Market Square. Other people on with their everyday lives but the sound is muffled and distant; she is lost in her own world. She stops on the brick star at the centre of the square. November 2003  86 INT. GRIET’S HOUSE DAY GRIET sits in the late afternoon sun near the back doorwa finishing her headdress. Her wedding dress is laid out on bed, other wedding preparations visible in the background TANNEKE appears at the door, out of breath. A moment's silence as they size each other up.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: I’ve come to the right place then.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Good Day, Tanneke.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: So it’s true, you‘re to be married.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Yes. TANNEKE nods, taking it in.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: We use another butcher nowadays. She searches in her apron pocket and brings out a small c wrapped package. She hands it to GRIET.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For you. I had to bring it myself - never mind that the dinner’s left to spoil. Men! She stops abruptly. GRIET holds the package gingerly, not to look at it.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best be off then.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: I'll see you to the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: TANNEKE
dialogues.text: No need for that. She turns away, her face working.

dialogues.speaker: GRIET
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tanneke. Left alone GRIET uncurls the hand gripping the package. S takes a deep breath then undces the layers of cloth, the familiar blue of the turban. And there, nestled in the fo fabric, lie the pearl earrings. November 2903  87 GRIET holds up one pale globe, fathoming its meaning, her shining with pent up tears.

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP ON
dialogues.text: A very slow pull back reveals the real painting: Girl Wit Pearl Earring. Cracked and aged but no less beautiful or immediate. A gi face as brim full of emotion as if she were looking at us November 2003
